Award.AwardTitle: Next Generation Ca-P Cements for Treating Vertebral Body Fractures

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Award # 1706513
PI: Bhaduri

This project will develop and characterize a novel material for the treatment of vertebral body compression fractures. This debilitating condition of the spine causes severe pain, reduced mobility, and potentially compromised organ function in a diverse segment of the population. The team will develop a next-generation, calcium phosphate-based orthopedic cement composition that, when injected at the fracture site, self-sets and develops strength within a short time without any generation of heat that could damage the surrounding tissue. Furthermore, the new material will be designed such that it has the ability to induce bone growth at the site of the fracture, which will improve healing. The innovation in this project is related to both the processing of the material and the choice of compositions. Working together, these two aspects of biomaterials development will create novel compositions with a diverse range of capabilities. These newly developed and optimized materials will be tested in a biomechanical model to mimic both normal and osteoporotic bone. The new material is expected to be cost effective, as the starting materials are simple chemicals. This project will integrate students of all levels, from high school through graduate students, into the laboratory. In addition, a mentoring program will be established with inner-city Toledo high schools to excite students about STEM fields, particularly related to bioengineering and manufacturing. Finally, a co-op program for undergraduate students will be developed in conjunction with the FDA to provide students with experience in medical device regulation.

The goal of this project is to design, optimize, and fully characterize - including through in vitro testing - novel compositions of a calcium phosphate-based orthopedic cement. The cement will be predominantly dicalcium phosphate anhydrous (CaHPO4, also known as monetite), which has optimized resorption kinetics and so supports biodegradation of the cement as the natural bone heals. The particles within the cement will be bonded with nano-silica to provide strength and osteoconductive properties. Additional osteoconduction can be generated due to the material?s ability to deliver bone morphogenic proteins to the affected site. The specific scientific objectives will be to: 1) develop, examine, and optimize the physical and mechanical characteristics of this next generation, calcium phosphate-based injectable orthopedic cement; 2) perform experimental studies on spinal models (both normal and osteoporotic) to determine the in vitro performance of the various cement compositions; and 3) evaluate the kinetics of bone morphogenic protein release from the cement as well as its impact on cell attachment and proliferation to the material surface.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to develop "Next-generation" multi-functional injectable calcium phosphate cement compositions (CPC) to treat ?Vertebral Body Compression Fractures (VCFs)?. This debilitating condition of the spine causes misery in a diverse population of the society, from young to the old. The multi-functionality includes injectability, the ability to self-set in a clinically relevant time frame without any exothermicity while attaining high strength. This combination of requirements is quite challenging and currently unavailable with the present products. Yet another aspect was to develop of antibacterial compositions of CPC cements. There is a need for the ?Next-Generation? compositions. This was a highly interdisciplinary project involving Materials Engineering, Bioengineering as well as clinical aspects such as Orthopedics.

Intrinsic merits

An important objective of the project was to develop, examine, and optimize the physical and mechanical characteristics of" new generation" smart Ca-P-based injectable cement compositions. The experimental work included the evaluation of phase(s), setting times, exothermicity, injectability, and mechanical strength. Tests included studying the stability of cements, cement cohesiveness in Phosphate Buffered Solutions (PBS), and cement acellular bioactivity behavior by soaking them in Simulated Body Fluid (SBF).

Broader impacts

Students at all levels (high school, undergraduate, and graduate) were benefitted from this project via classroom presentations, as well as laboratory work. As a new activity, the investigators participated in a newly established mentoring program involving students from the inner-city Toledo Public School to mentor them in engineering, especially in the areas of bioengineering and manufacturing.

 

For example, students from Perrysburg High School, OH and Bedford High School, MI received mentoring in terms of conducting physical properties characterization of as processed cements. Several undergraduate students were mentored in characterization methodologies. A team of students (ME majors) performed their capstone design assignment on cements to satisfy graduation requirements. Dr. Sikder, supported by the grant, finished his doctoral dissertation and is currently a tenure-track Assistant Professor at a doctoral-granting institution. He has co-authored a significant number of papers. Dr. Sikder also belonged to the very first cohorts of recipients of the Non-Academic Research Internships for Graduate Students (INTERN) program. He received hands-on experience in industrial projects at a global manufacturer of orthopedic implants.

 

The investigators disclosed the IP on actively smart CPC compositions and magnetic cement composition for treating tumors. The university filed a provisional patent. Some IP has been disclosed with the IP group at UT. Successful presentations were made to the patent committee and the university is going forward with the filing of provisional patents.

 This project was selected by the relevant professional society, The American Institute for Medical and Biological Engineering (AIMBE) for presentation at an exhibition organized by the Coalition for National Science Funding at the Capitol Hill (Figure1). The idea was to highlight research funded by the NSF to elected members of the Senate and the House of Representatives of this country. In view of the societal impacts of the project, it created a significant buzz. The relevant professional society, The American Institute for Medical and Biological Engineering (AIMBE) organized a high-level delegation to meet with the elected members of the Senate and the House of Representatives to "show and tell" the benefits biomedical research to the society. In view of the societal impacts of such research, the legislators (e.g., Sen. Brown and Sen. Portman of Ohio) and their staffers were interested in the present and future results of the project and listened to the PI with interest.
